answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Brian,
I found a few sources that should be useful to you.
North Carolina Department of Crime Control and Public Safety Proposed Contract for Debris Management Services. It encompasses the scope of services, monitoring and periodic reports, performance standards and general responsibilities. http://bit.ly/in5UIE 
A contract recommendations letter from a Consulting Company to the Town of Emerald Isle, NC provides an explanation of the selection process.   http://bit.ly/lpM87Z 
An article “FCO Brad Harris: Debris Cleanup is an Important Milestone in the Recovery Effort (Aug. 4, 2009)” that describes ways in which counties have found uses for recycled debris and reduced costs. http://www.fema.gov/hazard/hurricane/2008/ike/fco_archive.shtm 
And finally, the knowledge Network document, Picking Up Sticks Part 2: Specialized Debris, that explains the distinction between the debris and the standards that should be met by contractors in the removal process. http://icma.org/en/Article/100802/Picking_Up_Sticks_Part_2_Specialized_Debris 
I hope this is helpful,
Pooja Varma
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

author: Brian Halverson
text:
I am looking for examples of contracts for the clean up of brush and other bulky material after storm events/natural disasters.  Something that we would only use if the event is severe enough as to overwhelm our existing crews.
Thanks!
title: Disaster Debris Removal Contract
